posts.name: Caden Feller
posts.cooked:
Hello! I am a programmer of team 5480, we are using a 6 miniCIM drivetrain (3 on each side) and we keep browning out. With some clever math we have been able to eliminate most brownout scenarios, but we are still experiencing massive power draw. We cannot seem to figure out what it is. Our drivetrain has been repaired and it seems that it is working well enough that I shouldn’t be a problem (low amounts of friction) and all of the motors are working. Electrical systems have been looked over (its kind of hard to tell if the issue is electrical). Because there are no evident electrical or physical issues present, the blame has been passed on to me to fix the problem. I have gotten it to the point where it is no longer triggering the brownout protection, but our power levels are still dipping down to 7V. It still drives, but I feel like we are doing something wrong because I see tons of other teams doing this. Any tips for code or anything else to help? Much appreciated, Caden

P.S. My mentors are saying that our robot will be disabled by the field if our battery dips down below a certain value, but can’t remember what it is, and I couldn’t find anything in the game manual about this. Does anyone know if that is doable?

posts.name: Jeffrey Morris
posts.cooked:
BlackDiamond:

P.S. My mentors are saying that our robot will be disabled by the field if our battery dips down below a certain value, but can’t remember what it is, and I couldn’t find anything in the game manual about this. Does anyone know if that is doable?

I dont think this is correct, its on you not to brown out.

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked:
Can you tell us how ur batteries are constructed?

What’s the gearing for ur 6 cim drivetrain?

If you brownouts really bad (roborio gets less than 6ish or 5ish volts) I believe ur roborio will reset.  I doubt FTAs or refs will purposely disable ur robot.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: That’s a serious power draw and definitely not normal for the parts you described. We run 8 falcons + 4 775Pros and don’t have that much draw. Your electrical should be double / triple checked .

posts.name: Jeffrey Morris
posts.cooked: A good thing to check is what voltage are your baterries at when not running any motors, and how old are they?

posts.name: Caden Feller
posts.cooked: We are using the standard battery that comes with the KOP. Gearing is 3:1

posts.name: Caden Feller
posts.cooked: We have double and triple checked all of our electrical. There dont seem to be any issues. What in particular do you think we could have wrong?

posts.name: Caden Feller
posts.cooked: They are at 12V, they are various ages, all from before covid.

posts.name: NatsirtD
posts.cooked:
BlackDiamond:

Gearing is 3:1

What wheel size? With 4 or 6 inch wheels this is an incredibly low ratio and would make sense that brownouts occur.

BlackDiamond:

They are at 12V, they are various ages, all from before covid.

This is probably another issue, batteries should be over 13 volts when fully charged. Batteries this old probably have degraded enough that even a large normal amount of current draw would cause you to brown out.

posts.name: Jeffrey Morris
posts.cooked: 12V its low for a freshly charged battery, ours are right at 13V off the charger and onto the bot. It also sounds like they are pretty old, for frc anyway, we buy 2 batteries every year and use the most recent 2 years meaning we use 4 batteries at competition, one on the bot and 3 charged/charging. When a battery gets old it wont hold its charge as well as a new battery. Do take everything I say with a grain of salt as I am a programmer and not electrical lol, they could be fine and it be some other problem.

posts.name: Caden Feller
posts.cooked:
They’re 6 in wheels.

Can we get batteries at places other than AndyMark?

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked:
Let’s eliminate some variables. Did you receive a new battery this year? Can you check to see if you are having brownouts with this new battery.

Also, Check that ur batteries are constructed thusly:

The power supply for an FRC ® robot is a single 12V 18Ah SLA (Sealed Lead Acid) non-spillable battery, capable of briefly supplying over 180A and arcing over 500A when fully charged. The Robot Batt...

link_counts.title: Robot Battery Basics — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: NatsirtD
posts.cooked: A 3:1 gear ratio is way too low for 6 inch wheels. This puts your max speed at over 50 feet per second, and is likely drawing over 200 amps while trying to accelerate(causing brownouts). You can buy batteries from MK Battery for a bit cheaper than Andymark.

posts.name: Caden Feller
posts.cooked: We did not get a new battery this year.

posts.name: Caden Feller
posts.cooked: I was misinformed. The true ratio is about 1:7.3

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked:
Do a quick test - run each motor independently, one at a time, in the drive train.  You want to make sure that “forward” is actually forward for all of them.  Having your motors fighting each other is a sure path to power issues!

Have you looked at the DS log viewer?  You should be able to see current draw per channel on there.  Look at all 6 channels used for your drive train and see if there are any anomalies - is anything drawing more current than the others?

You say you keep browning out, but don’t give us a time frame.  Does it happen immediately, as soon as you start driving?  Or does it take a few minutes before you hit brown out?  Every robot, if driven long enough, will hit brown out conditions as the battery discharges.  It may be a problem if it happens fast enough, but if it’s taking 20 minutes to hit brown out, then you’re fine!

I’ll echo people above concerned about the age and condition of your batteries.

posts.name: Caden Feller
posts.cooked: I appreciate the advice, we actually had to fix an issue where one of our motors was not running, and it was causing immediate brown outs - so much that I would lose communications with the robot for about a minute or so. We got a chance to check that out when that happened. As far as currently, the DS log viewer showed that one of the motors was not pulling any current. The motor controller is getting power, and it is receiving the signal to move forward (or reverse) but the motor is not pulling any voltage when moving forward. We double checked that the electrical connection is strong. It also does not experience any issues when driving (for contrast, when one of our motors was dead, the robot would shut off completely and immediately when trying to move the side of the drivetrain that had the motor on it) , and the voltage seems normal when running in reverse, but when driving forward, it doesn’t recognize any voltage draw. I get the feeling that it is a sensor issue, but I figured I’d mention it since you asked. We are looking into getting new batteries. Thanks for all the advice, I never would have thought about the batteries being an issue.

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: You can get new ones at Batteries Plus, but they are more expensive. You can just bring in an old battery and they’ll be able to grab the correct one for you, just double check it against the rules.

posts.name: Caden Feller

posts.name: Pizzatc
posts.cooked:
Our team was having pretty bad brownout’s last year. We were running 15 motors and it might have been understandable that we had too many motors until we found out some teams were running 16+ motors. For the situation you described my guess is your Battery leads.

My reasoning is that we had been reusing battery leads that were about 3+ years old, we eventually took a closer look and they had corrosion on the Anderson part and that it had corrosion that was causing resistance, in addition we were reusing breaker leads instead of making our own.

In addition using batteries that are almost 3 years old is not good for playing matches, maybe testing and lighter tasks.

So my recommendation is if you can afford it is buy some battery leads from andymark(I highly recommend buying over making your own battery leads) and I recommend if you reuse breaker leads to consider making your own. I also recommend buying some new batteries.
